title: State of AI in 2026: LLMs, Coding, Scaling Laws, China, Agents, GPUs, AGI
description: Lex Fridman Podcast episode #490 covering the state of AI in 2026, with deep dives into LLMs, coding with AI, scaling laws, agents, GPUs, and progress toward AGI. Provides comprehensive overview of AI landscape as of January 2026.
author: Lex Fridman

title: I replaced a $120/year micro-SaaS in 20 minutes with LLM-generated code
description: Pragmatic Engineer demonstrates real-world LLM code generation capabilities by replacing a $120/year micro-SaaS product in just 20 minutes. Illustrates the growing power of AI coding tools for rapid application development.
author: Pragmatic Engineer

title: Ex-Tesla AI Boss Notices 'Atrophy' of Manual Coding Skills
description: Business Insider covers Andrej Karpathy's experience with AI coding causing skill atrophy. The article discusses how Karpathy shifted from 80% manual coding to 80% AI agent coding, raising concerns about maintaining fundamental programming skills as AI tools become more capable.
author: Business Insider

title: Software 3.0: Andrej Karpathy's Vision for AI, LLMs, and Agents
description: Medium article discussing Karpathy's vision for Software 3.0, exploring the transformation of software development through AI agents and LLMs. Covers the fundamental shift in how software is built and the implications for the future of programming.
author: Data Science Collective

title: Modelence raises $3M to smooth out the vibe-coding stack
description: Modelence, a Y Combinator-backed developer tools startup, raised $3M in seed funding to solve fragmentation in the 'vibe-coding' movement. The company provides a batteries-included framework for AI software development and addresses DevOps challenges in AI growth. Investors include Rebel Fund, Acacia Venture Capital Partners, and Audium Capital Partners.
author: TechCrunch

title: Tiny startup Arcee AI built a 400B-parameter open source LLM from scratch
description: TechCrunch reports on Arcee AI building a 400B-parameter open source LLM that beats Meta's LLaMA. Highlights the trend of smaller teams building competitive large language models, with implications for AI coding and developer tools.
author: TechCrunch

title: Adding dynamic features to an aggressively cached website
description: Simon Willison discusses techniques for adding dynamic features to his heavily cached blog (behind Cloudflare with 15-minute cache headers). Explores how to maintain aggressive static site caching while incorporating dynamic functionality.
author: Simon Willison

title: ChatGPT Containers can now run bash, pip/npm install packages, and download files
description: Simon Willison discovers major upgrades to ChatGPT's code interpreter feature, now called ChatGPT Containers. Key new capabilities: direct Bash command execution, Node.js and 10+ additional language support (Ruby, Perl, PHP, Go, Java, Swift, Kotlin, C, C++), pip/npm package installation via internal proxy, and container.download tool to fetch files from the web. Simon tests security implications and documents the internal proxy mechanism.
author: Simon Willison

title: Karpathy's Claude Code Field Notes: Coding Workflow Transformation
description: Andrej Karpathy shares detailed notes on his seismic shift from 80% manual coding to 80% AI agent coding in just weeks. His workflow transformation occurred between November-December 2025 when LLM agent capabilities crossed a threshold of coherence. Discusses IDE vs agent swarms, model mistakes, tenacity of agents, speedups, leverage patterns, skill atrophy concerns, and predictions for the 'slopacolypse' of 2026. This represents a phase shift in software engineering practices.
author: Andrej Karpathy

title: AI Coding Dominates 2026: Week of January 20-27
description: Weekly recap highlighting AI coding developments, including mentions of MCP (Model Context Protocol) as the standard way for AI agents to connect with external data sources and tools.
author: Alex Merced

title: Current AI Agent Landscape: Jan 2026
description: Medium article discussing the current state of AI agents in January 2026, highlighting how 'You don't need to build AI agents anymore. Code is all you need' - reflecting on the shift toward code-based agent orchestration over specialized agent frameworks.
author: Yashwanth Sai
